choices.text: Rhomboidal, weakly positive refringent crystals under polarising microscopy
Needle shaped, strongly negative birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy

questions.text: A 74-year-old female presented with sudden onset pain and swelling in the left knee. On examination she is afebrile. X-ray shows chondrocalcinosis. Microscopic analysis of the synovial fluid is most likely to show:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rhomboidal, weakly positive refringent crystals under polarising microscopy. The patient presents with sudden onset pain and swelling in the knee, accompanied by chondrocalcinosis on X-ray, which is highly suggestive of pseudogout. Pseudogout is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals in the joints. The hallmark feature on synovial fluid analysis under polarising microscopy is the identification of rhomboidal crystals that exhibit weakly positive birefringence. This is characteristic of CPPD crystals, which are the causative factor in pseudogout. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A) Atypical mononuclear cells: Atypical mononuclear cells may be seen in a variety of conditions involving joint inflammation or infections, but they are not characteristic of pseudogout. The primary finding in pseudogout is the presence of CPPD crystals in the synovial fluid, not abnormal mononuclear cells. This answer choice is more aligned with viral arthritis or other forms of inflammatory arthritis, but not pseudogout. B) Tophi: Tophi are characteristic of gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals, not calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals. Tophi are visible in chronic gout cases, typically as nodules around affected joints. In contrast, pseudogout is associated with rhomboidal crystals (CPPD) and not tophi. This makes option B incorrect for the diagnosis of pseudogout. D) Needle shaped, strongly negative birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy: This description of needle-shaped, strongly negative birefringent crystals is characteristic of gout, where monosodium urate (MSU) crystals deposit in the joints. Gout and pseudogout both present with acute arthritis but are caused by different types of crystals. While gout involves MSU crystals, pseudogout involves CPPD crystals, which are rhomboidal and exhibit weak positive birefringence, not the needle-shaped crystals associated with gout.

questions.text: All the following statements about Gouty arthritis are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 90% caused by overproduction of Uric acid. Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints due to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood). However, 90% of gout cases are caused by underexcretion of uric acid rather than overproduction. The kidneys are unable to excrete enough uric acid, leading to its accumulation in the blood. Only about 10% of cases are caused by overproduction of uric acid, typically due to inherited metabolic disorders or increased turnover of cells. Therefore, option A is incorrect. Why the Other Options Are Correct: B) Uric acid levels may be normal at the time of acute attack: During an acute gouty attack, uric acid levels in the blood can actually be normal or even low despite the presence of urate crystals in the joint. This can happen because the inflammatory process in the joint leads to a transient drop in uric acid levels in the bloodstream. Therefore, normal uric acid levels at the time of an acute attack do not rule out the diagnosis of gout. This statement is true. C) Men more likely affected than females: Gout is much more common in men than in women, particularly before menopause. In men, gout typically occurs when uric acid levels exceed the renal excretion capacity, leading to crystal deposition in joints. In women, the incidence of gout is lower until after menopause, when estrogen levels decrease, potentially contributing to the development of hyperuricemia. This statement is true. D) Definitive diagnosis requires synovial fluid aspirate: The definitive diagnosis of gout requires the identification of monosodium urate crystals in the synovial fluid or joint aspirate. These crystals will appear as needle-shaped and will show negative birefringence under polarized light microscopy. While clinical presentation and elevated uric acid levels can suggest gout, the synovial fluid aspiration is necessary for a definitive diagnosis. This statement is true.

questions.text: A 53-year Male comes with sudden onset severe pain in first metatarsophalangeal joint. He is a K/C/O gout. His laboratory investigations reveal HB – 9.8, Uric Acid – 11.2 and Creatinine -3.4mg/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intra-articular steroids. This patient is presenting with an acute gout attack in the first metatarsophalangeal joint, which is the most common joint affected in gout. However, the patient also has significant renal impairment (elevated creatinine of 3.4 mg/dL) and a high uric acid level (11.2 mg/dL). Given the patient's renal dysfunction, certain treatments for gout may be contraindicated or require adjustment. Intra-articular corticosteroids are a good option for treating acute gout attacks in patients who cannot safely use NSAIDs due to renal impairment or other contraindications. Steroids help to control inflammation and pain in the affected joint without impacting kidney function. They provide rapid relief and are effective in treating local inflammation associated with gout. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A) Allopurinol: Allopurinol is a urate-lowering therapy that is used to prevent future gout attacks by lowering uric acid levels in the blood. However, starting allopurinol during an acute gout attack is not recommended, as it can worsen the attack due to the shift in uric acid levels. It is typically started only after the acute episode has resolved. Additionally, in patients with renal impairment, dosing of allopurinol must be adjusted carefully. Therefore, allopurinol is not the first-line treatment during an acute attack. B) NSAIDs: NSAIDs are commonly used to treat the pain and inflammation associated with acute gout attacks. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated in this patient due to renal impairment (creatinine of 3.4 mg/dL), as they can further compromise kidney function, potentially leading to acute kidney injury. Given the patient's renal condition, NSAIDs should be avoided in favor of safer alternatives like steroids. D) Febuxostat: Febuxostat is another urate-lowering therapy like allopurinol but is generally not recommended during an acute attack. It also works by lowering uric acid levels, which can trigger or worsen the inflammatory response during an acute flare. Like allopurinol, febuxostat is best started after the acute attack has resolved and once the patient is stabilized. Additionally, febuxostat should be used cautiously in patients with renal impairment, though it is generally considered safer than allopurinol in such cases. However, it is not suitable as first-line therapy during an acute attack.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with the acute onset of severe pain in the great toe of his right foot that developed over a few hours. He had one episode like this before a few months ago. Pain came on very suddenly, and his toe is clearly red and warm. He is not taking any medicines. On examination- Great toe of right foot is warm, red, and extremely tender. Overlying skin is tense. Lab Reports: blood urea 51 mg/dL (elevated); creatinine 1.8 mg/dL (elevated), Uric acid level: 7.2 mg/dL. All the following medicines can be used now
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intra-articular Steroids Intra-articular corticosteroids are a first-line treatment for acute gout, especially when 1–2 joints are involved. They are particularly useful in patients with renal impairment, as in this case, where NSAIDs and colchicine may pose risks. They provide rapid, localized anti-inflammatory effect without systemic toxicity. This patient has a single joint (great toe) affected and significant renal dysfunction, making intra-articular steroids both safe and effective. Incorrect Options: B. Indomethacin Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used in acute gout. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated or should be avoided in patients with impaired renal function, as they can further reduce renal perfusion and exacerbate kidney injury. Given this patient’s elevated creatinine and blood urea, indomethacin is not a safe option. C. Anakinra Anakinra is an IL-1 receptor antagonist used in refractory or severe cases of gout or when standard therapies (NSAIDs, colchicine, steroids) are contraindicated. It is safe in renal impairment and can be used here. However, it is not always the first-line therapy due to cost and availability. It can be used in this patient. D. All This option is incorrect because not all listed drugs are appropriate for this patient. Indomethacin is contraindicated due to renal dysfunction, making "All" an incorrect choice.

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette patient was given intra articular steroids. He responded well to acute treatment. To prevent further attack which food items will you tell him to avoid.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Steak and beer. In patients with gout, the goal is to prevent future flare-ups by managing uric acid levels. The condition is caused by elevated levels of uric acid, which form crystals in the joints, especially in the big toe. The consumption of purine-rich foods leads to an increase in uric acid levels, triggering gout attacks. Steak and beer are both high in purines, which are broken down into uric acid. Red meat (like steak) and alcohol, especially beer, are known to significantly contribute to elevated uric acid levels. Beer contains high levels of purines from yeast, and it can also lead to dehydration, which exacerbates gout. Therefore, patients with gout are advised to limit or avoid red meats and beer to prevent further attacks. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A) Milk and cheese: Milk and cheese are low in purines, making them less likely to cause a flare-up of gout. In fact, dairy products, especially low-fat options, are generally recommended for people with gout because they have been shown to help lower uric acid levels. Milk is considered beneficial for gout patients due to its ability to increase the excretion of uric acid through the kidneys. C) Butter and eggs: Butter and eggs are also low in purines. While they should be consumed in moderation for general health reasons (due to their high fat content), they do not significantly affect uric acid levels or trigger gout attacks. Eggs are considered a neutral food with respect to gout. D) Gluten (wheat)-containing foods: There is no significant evidence linking gluten-containing foods with the exacerbation of gout. While some individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity might need to avoid gluten, it is not a known trigger for gout attacks. Therefore, this is not a concern for a patient with gout unless there is an underlying gluten intolerance, which is not mentioned in the vignette.

choices.text: Urate crystal deposition in renal tubules
Inhibition of filtration at the glomerulus

questions.text: A 40 year old male known case of hypertension on thiazide presented with pain at great toe associated with redness and swelling. He gives history of such pain in the past off and on. Lab tests shows BUN 25 g/dL (elevated); creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (elevated)Uric acid level: 7.8 mg/dL . What is the mechanism of renal dysfunction in gout?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Urate crystal deposition in renal tubules. In patients with gout, renal dysfunction occurs primarily due to the deposition of urate crystals in the renal tubules. This condition is called gouty nephropathy. When uric acid levels in the blood become excessively high (hyperuricemia), urate crystals can form and deposit in the kidneys, specifically in the renal tubules, leading to acute or chronic kidney damage. These deposits can cause inflammation, obstruction, and scarring, which contribute to renal impairment. In this patient, elevated levels of BUN (25 mg/dL) and creatinine (2.1 mg/dL), along with elevated uric acid levels (7.8 mg/dL), suggest gout with possible renal involvement, particularly in the form of urate crystal deposition in the renal tubules. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A) Vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole: While vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole can lead to decreased renal perfusion and may contribute to hypertensive nephropathy, it is not the primary mechanism of renal dysfunction in gout. In gout, the main issue is the deposition of urate crystals in the kidneys, not vasoconstriction. Thiazide diuretics, which this patient is taking, can also cause volume depletion, potentially leading to increased uric acid levels and gout, but again, vasoconstriction is not the primary cause of renal dysfunction in this scenario. C) Obstructive renal stones: Obstructive renal stones can certainly cause renal dysfunction and are a known complication of gout, but urate crystal deposition in the renal tubules is more directly related to the mechanism of renal dysfunction in gout. Uric acid stones can form in the kidneys and cause obstruction, but this is a later-stage complication of chronic gout rather than the primary cause of renal dysfunction in the acute setting. D) Inhibition of filtration at the glomerulus: In gout, there is no direct inhibition of glomerular filtration itself. The problem is uric acid crystal deposition in the renal tubules, leading to obstruction and kidney damage. While glomerular filtration rate (GFR) may decrease as a result of overall kidney dysfunction, the primary mechanism is not inhibition of filtration, but rather the consequences of uric acid crystal deposition in the renal structures.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man has recurrent attacks of pain, swelling, and redness in his left knee. He has background osteoarthritis of both knees, which require him to take acetaminophen on a regular basis. Joint fluid was removed during one acute episode of knee pain, and synovial fluid analysis revealed calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease crystals (CPPD). Which of the following methods is the most effective prophylaxis for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Colchicine. Colchicine is the most effective prophylactic treatment for calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD) to prevent recurrent acute attacks of joint inflammation. It works by inhibiting neutrophil activity, reducing the inflammatory response to crystal deposition in the joint. While it does not directly affect the formation or deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals, its anti-inflammatory effects make it effective in reducing the frequency of acute flares when used as a low-dose prophylactic medication. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A) Allopurinol: Allopurinol is used to lower uric acid levels in patients with gout by reducing uric acid production. However, it has no effect on CPPD, as the crystals in CPPD are composed of calcium pyrophosphate, not urate. Thus, allopurinol is not effective in preventing CPPD flares. B) Continuous NSAIDs: While NSAIDs are useful for managing acute flares of CPPD by reducing inflammation and pain, they are not the most effective option for long-term prophylaxis. Prolonged use of NSAIDs can lead to side effects such as gastrointestinal irritation, renal impairment, and cardiovascular risks, making them less suitable for chronic prophylaxis. C) Low-dose glucocorticoids: Low-dose glucocorticoids may help control inflammation during acute CPPD attacks, but they are not commonly used for long-term prophylaxis due to the potential for significant side effects, including osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, and increased infection risk. They are typically reserved for patients who cannot tolerate colchicine or NSAIDs.
